description.text: I use this container to store various items. The two smaller compartments and the height of the overall container are designed to fit these 30 ml plastic dropping bottles. http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0026K1YCK/ref=oh_details_o05_s01_i00

So you want to attach a Bowden extruder with BSP push fitting connector to your Prusa i2 RepRap? Maybe this will help. It fits on the standard i2 x-carriage for rapid testing, and it mounts a jHead Mk V BV hot end. Note that you should always measure the top of your hotend to make sure this will fit.

• Incudes an inner taper to help the initial filament feed through with increased ease.
• Was modeled to work with this extruder by Airtripper and a horizontal x-carriage plane.

description.header: The precompiled .STL file included in this Thing has:
description.text:
• A filament feed hole diameter of 3mm, but I have been using it with 1.75mm filament for the past year with no problems.
  • A mount hole for a BSP fitting with a 10.5mm base
    • Please report any problems below.

You will need a BSP push fitting, an M3 nut and an M3 screw of at least 10 mm length. Print, place the nut in the trap and thread the screw inwards through the hole. Insert the threaded BSP fitting and tighten the screw a little bit to make it snug.
To attach to a hot end, you'll need an aluminum or similar mounting plate. This version requires M3 screws to mount the hot end and plate securely, but you can change that in the code.
Please read the comments in the code and check that the variables match your equipment and hardware dimensions before printing.

comments.text:
Hey! Just want to say I'm currently printing this object. I was looking for a slot-mount capture for J-Head with a BSP installed in it already, but looking at this I'll probably just try your design instead and use a normal JHead.
One suggestion: You should put more details on the dimensions for your pre-compiled STL. For example: filament diameter (1.75 vs 3mm), BSP threadied-end diameter (1/8"? M5?), etc.
comments.author: PhatJustice

comments.text: Thanks for the tip. I made some changes; I'm just now realizing that people are just wanting to print the STL instead of deal with my messy SCAD code. :D

Hey, I'm sorry to hear that.

title: Auto bed-level for Prusa i3 Rework

description.text:
This is an auto bed-level mount for the extruder that comes with the i3 Rework parts.
It can be printed without supports. This was made on Tinkercad. You can copy and edit it here: https://tinkercad.com/things/dsifjfE9IBQ-auto-bed-level-v3/

The mount is attached to the extruder by means of the 2 M3 screws that hold the hotend in place, and has a place to mount the M3 nuts so it's easy to detach if needed.
The Z-probe is somewhat generic. It allows you to insert a servo-head into it and glue it with epoxy, but I'll improve on it soon.
The servo is a generic micro servo.
In my case, I have Saintsmart endstops (PCB) so I de-soldered the actual endstop from it and wired a bigger one which I mounted on the z-probe. Then, I mounted the PCB to the top of the support. This way, I have the LED available for calibration.

comments.text: I really like what you have done here.  I however, have no need to use the led setup, but the hole in the top with a little modification is a perfect opening to allow the big gear space to spin when mounted on the other side of the extruder, also I installed the servo the other way around (fits inside the big piece perfectly I might add) and only had to notch out a very small amount of the zprobe to get the servo bar to fit snuggly into it without epoxy (will post pics soon).  I have been motivated by your invention so thank you. I will create my first thing before the end of the weekend. I also had major flaws with my firmware settings (went from i3 rework to a larger, sturdier Wilson TS - X axis is identical just longer) so this is the first thing I have printed to completion in over 2 weeks.  FINALLY!!     Really good idea with this thing though I have been waiting for someone to come up with something for auto leveling the stock i3 rework so I didn't have to print out a whole new set of parts as there are not many for the Wilson yet

author: squareoctopus

title: Geared Cube, Motorized Edition
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Well, just because I had to. Emmett's geared cube, motorized. Video here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lAlLrBzuFFo. Printed in PLA on a Makerbot Replicator 2 using Makerware 2.3.3.42 "Standard" settings.

Study "Assembly.skp". Obtain the following parts: 1) Gear Motor - "6VDC 45 RPM Pinky Finger Sized Gear Motor 1" Long x 15/32" x 3/8"" from either amazon.com or directly from http://sciplus.com/p/MICROMOTOR_47952. Other sources are available, I've not tested them though. 2) Coaxial Power Jack - Radio Shack part number 274-1583. 3) 1.5 Vdc Power Supply - Radio Shack part number 273-315 with the "N" style plug (273-345, you get one free with the power supply). Print emmett's "CubeGears2-3.stl". If you can edit the file, you can delete one of the large corners, the center hub, and one pin before printing as these parts are not used. Clean up any stray filament in the gear holes. See Geared Heart, Motorized Edition (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:271612) for the steps I performed in loosening up the geared cube as the it must spin freely. Print all parts. While printing "Top.stl", I paused the printer at 4.2mm and changed filament from black to silver. Test fit, file, sand, etc. for smooth operation. Lubricate the gears and any surface contact between rotating components Solder a wire between the motor plus terminal and the coaxial power jack center pin. Solder a wire between the motor minus terminal and the coaxial power jack shell pin. Plug in the power supply, and test. I run mine at 6VDC for an hour or so for break in, then switch to 1.5VDC for actual running. If yours doesn't run at 1.5VDC, then disassemble the cube gear, and re-tune the pins in the gear holes. Hope you like it.

This is a adapter to allow your filament spool to easily rotate on a rod.
You can adjust many of the parameters and dimensions of the spool bushing in the .scad file or Customizer.
The .stl files have the dimensions for a 32mm spool mount and 8mm rod.
The printed bushings in the pictures were my first attempt at the design, but after cracking both bushings, I made the walls thicker and added several improvements to the design.

Print two of these and push them into the holes on your filament spool while they are still hot.
I prefer ABS, but PLA works, too.
There are instructions in the .scad file on editing the parameters.
If you make one, please share it under the "Made" tab!

EDIT: see my remix: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:291110
its faster and better to print and need mutch less support!
(thanks to: Supercockroach ) my son whanted the nightfury dragon from "how to train a dragon" movie. (it is his favorit movie).
so i searched the net for a 3d objekt and finaly after long long search, if found it (it is not created be me)! i have sliced it up a bit and added support material with meshmixer.
while printing (4 hours at 50mm/s) some of the supports broken and the hotend crashed into the objekt, so it dont looks nice. tomrow i whant to add a bigger support material with meshmixer and then i try to print a better one for him and then we paint it to look more real. support material can be easy removed with the meshmixer support, its realy mutch better then the standart support from cura. printer: prusa i2
hotend: merlin
nozzle: 0.3mm
speed: 50mm/s
filament: PLA / 3mm
layerhigh: 0.2 EDIT:
i have added another one with bigger supports, so it dont breaks that easy while printing...

author: smatt44

title: Clips and Spacer for Ninja Printer Plate VERSION 2 (MakerBot Replicator 2)

description.text: NOTE: This is for version 2 of the the Ninja Printer Plate, and it won't work with original version. Version 2 is slightly thinner, which is why it requires a different spacer and clips. The spacer and clips for the original Ninja Printer Plate can be found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:252400 I bought a Ninja Printer Plate, but had a hard time making it work with my MakerBot Replicator 2. While binder clips kept it attached to the existing build plate, they were difficult to attach and got in the way of the extruder. Also, the existing build plate isn't adjustable enough to make room for the extra thickness of the additional plate. So, I made some clips and a spacer. The clips are small and low-profile, so they don't impede the extruder or limit the build area. The spacer activates the z-axis switch, making room for the extra thickness of the Ninja plate. The link for the plate: http://printinz.com/printer-plates/

The clips were designed to work with the existing MakerBot Replicator 2 acrylic build plate. I use 4-8 at a time, depending on the size of the print. If you need to modify them, I've included the SketchUp file. I printed them with PLA at 100% fill, 3 shells. The spacer sits on the build platform carriage, right below the Z-axis switch. See the photo for placement. You'll need to re-level the build platform after adding it. The spacer only needs minimal fill. I don't work for Ninja, I'm just a customer. But it's a great plate! Parts stick extremely well, but the plate can be flexed to release them. Much easier and than tape, hairspray, etc. Truly worth every penny. If you're interested in the Ninja Printer Plate, the company sells it here: http://printinz.com/printer-plates/

comments.text: I am blown away by the Ninja Printer plate 2! We got ours this morning and the results are night and day over the blue tape! The board seems like a perfect match for the printer! I would highly suggest if you are having even slight issues with warping and torn blue tape to invest is this board!
comments.author: wwhaley

comments.text: I couldn't agree more!
comments.author: wwhaley

comments.text: I printed the spacer just as it comes in the file. And I see exactly where to put it. However, what I can't figure out is how to get it to stay there? Do I glue it in place? It's the exact size of the space, so it doesn't snap in or anything. I welcome your thoughts, and thanks for doing this project!
comments.author: crafty184

comments.text: It just sits there. Gravity should keep it in place just fine. I don't recommend glue, since it make removing the spacer difficult if you want to change plates or beds.
comments.author: crafty184

author: TobyGadd

description.text: Just a simple vase.

title: Pentagonal Hexacontahedron Bracelet
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This bracelet is formed from a ring of irregular pentagons taken from the center of a Pentagonal Hexacontahedron. So not only do you get a fancy bracelet, you also get to sound all fancy when you tell people what it is. STL files are included for small and large versions. The large should fit over most hands and form a bangle bracelet. The small is for more lady-like hands. For those with larger hands like me, you can cut off a couple of rungs of the small version to make a C-shaped bracelet that is easy to put on and take off, and fits more snugly. Featured on Day 218 of MakerHome: http://makerhome.blogspot.com/2014/04/day-218-polygiraffe-bracelet.html UPDATE: Now available printed in Nylon or Metal at Shapeways. =====

This design and all associated pictures and files are licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial Share Alike license. If you want to use designs, images, or files outside of the terms of this license, please email [email protected].
